Sometimes I don't want to outsource work. Where should I draw the line?

Read

by nolen royalty

media & speakingblog & all workwhat's my deal

eieio.games

by nolen royalty

media & speakingblog & all workwhat's my deal

Will AI Pet My Dog for Me?

What work do I want to skip?

Jan 19, 2026

I have a dog. Her name is Gabby. She‚Äôs lovely.

Gabby and me last summer

She‚Äôs a lot of work. A dog walker handles Gabby‚Äôs afternoon walks. It‚Äôs nice to outsource the afternoon walk since it interrupts my day.

Gabby‚Äôs appetite for play and affection is insatiable. I sometimes want to outsource more of the work of taking care of her.

To align my goals of ‚Äúbuilding as much weird software as possible‚Äù and ‚Äútaking care of my dog,‚Äù I could outsource all of the work of caring for Gabby. Someone else could walk her and feed her and pet her, leaving me free to find better UUIDs.

My time is valuable; this would be an efficient use of my money.

But I don‚Äôt do that. I like petting my dog.

I like to understand

I like to understand things. I like to share that understanding with others. This is my favorite part of building software. Until recently I had to understand the software that I developed.

LLMs can now type most of my code for me. And if I want, I can often accept that code without understanding how it works. That‚Äôs a big change.

LLMs have changed a lot of things! I am good at generating lots of code quickly; that skill is less valuable than it was 5 years ago. I‚Äôm pretty quick in vim; that‚Äôs probably not as important either.

It‚Äôs uncomfortable that some skills I‚Äôve honed over years are becoming less valuable. But code has fussy syntax, boring parts, and boilerplate. It‚Äôs exciting to have agents that can take my code on its afternoon walk.

It‚Äôs more uncomfortable to be able to skip the understanding. For me, that‚Äôs petting the dog.

I can still choose to understand

Many of my blogs are about understanding useless computer problems. They would be bad posts if they said ‚ÄúI asked an LLM to solve this problem and it did.‚Äù

I did not do this

Nobody can make me use LLM outputs that I don‚Äôt understand for this blog.

But my blog‚Äôs style doesn‚Äôt control the software industry. Understanding can be a chore or expense on the way to shipping. Maybe it doesn‚Äôt make sense to pay to pet the dog anymore.

That may change the internet‚Äôs appetite for my explanations. Selfishly, I hope people still enjoy reading them. I hope that I still want to write them.

Humans like to understand

Understanding is fun even when it isn‚Äôt necessary.

Bartosz Ciechanowski‚Äôs blog is a wonder of the internet. It‚Äôs all illustrations of things that I don‚Äôt need to understand. Primitive Technology is an extremely popular youtube channel about building things in nature from scratch. My favorite video game is about understanding a new world.

The joy of understanding is a core human experience for me. If you read my blog, I bet it is for you too.

I don‚Äôt understand what comes next

Lots of LLM discussion is about whether programmers are about to be out of a job. I have nothing to contribute there. And if you‚Äôre talking about this blog on the internet, I‚Äôd like to nudge you away from a discussion you‚Äôve probably had too many times in the past 3 years.

My immediate fear isn‚Äôt that I‚Äôll be out of a job. My fear is that I‚Äôll lose the part of my job that I love the most.

That fear may be wildly off base. Maybe LLM-assisted coding will just change what I need to understand and give me more time than ever to pet the dog. It‚Äôs hard to say.

But regardless, I‚Äôm confident that I‚Äôll still love understanding for its own sake. I think you will too. That‚Äôs comforting to me.

Anyway. Here‚Äôs Gabby starting to understand how to rebound a balloon.

She's pretty good at this now.

Thanks for reading!

Keep up with me on my socials üëÜ

Or sub to my newsletter here! üëá
